In light of the discussions that go on in this forum this is quite a relevant subject.
 
 I think pain is an interesting example as in many instances it is successfully catagorised as is a psychological perception of a physilogical effect (like an injury).
 
 An objective measurement of pain is difficult and will often rely on a qualitative measure to rate how severe it is- ie. a patient is assessed according to their perception of the pain. Given the highly individual nature of people and they illnesses they suffer I suppose this is not surprising.
 
 In the case of injury awareness of the the likelyhood of impending injury also effects how it is felt. A person who sees an injury coming will feel its effects very strongly and quickly whereas someone caught unawares may not feel much discomfort at all as their nervous system floods the brain with messages that cannot be immediately understood.
 
 Other things effect how people behave- damage to areas of the brain and release of endomorphins/adrenaline can mask a persons comprehension of an injury allowing some very serious injurys to go unfelt for many hours.
 
 
 Still, pain is a result of nervous impulses that are interpreted by the brain to produce a comprehensible feeling. The intangibility comes from the very varied ways in which people react to those effects.
